A 'Blue Corner Notice' seeking information on his whereabouts has already been issued by the Interpol, following a request by the SIT via the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI).A Special Court for Elected Representatives issued an arrest warrant on May 18 against Prajwal Revanna, following an application moved by the SIT. The Congress-led Karnataka government has urged the Centre to cancel his diplomatic passport.
Article Summary: Hassan MP Prajwal Revanna is facing charges of sexually abusing women. He left for Germany on April 27, a day after Hassan went to polls, and is still at large. A 'Blue Corner Notice' seeking information on his whereabouts has already been issued by Interpol.

Article Title: INLD Ambala candidate issued notice of election code violation
Article Text:
Representative Image

AMBALA: The nodal officer (complaints) for model code of conduct (MCC) of 2024 Lok Sabha election in Ambala on Tuesday issued notice to Indian National Lok Dal (INLD) Ambala candidate Gurpreet Singh, for MCC violation during the elections. The INLD candidate has been asked to submit a written reply to the notice by 11 am on May 30.

The notice has been issued taking cognizance of a TOI report published on Tuesday. The notice said that it has come to his notice of nodal officer MCC (complaints) that during the voting on May 25, at 3:31 pm, a video has been posted through the social media Facebook account of Advocate Sardar Gurpreet Singh Sahota, in which a person is shown pressing the EVM button and voting at the VVPAT machine in a 17-second video taken from a mobile phone and this video post has been uploaded with the caption "Ambala rachne ja raha hai itehas! Apne nete Gurpreet ke saath", which has been found to be a violation of the MCC.

Before taking further action as per rules against the INLD candidate for disobeying the MCC, he has been asked to submit your written reply in this regard, otherwise further action will be taken as per rules.
Article Summary: The notice has been issued to the INLD candidate for the 24th Lok Sabha election, Gurpreet Singh. The candidate has been asked to submit a written reply to the notice by 11 am on May 30. The notice was issued in response to a video posted on social media showing the candidate pressing the VVPAT button.

Article Title: PM Modi to meditate in Kanyakumari for 3 days from May 30
Article Text:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi meditating inside a cave at Kedarnath (File photo)

CHENNAI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi will arrive in Kanyakumari on May 30, when campaigning for the final phase of the ongoing parliamentary elections ends, to begin a three-day meditation. During his stay, the Prime Minister will be at the Rock Memorial’s Dhyan Mandapam, the site where Swami Vivekananda meditated in 1892. At the end of the election campaigns in 2014 and 2019 too, Modi had made similar trips – the first time to Shivaji’s Pratapgarh and on the second occasion to a cave near the Kedarnath temple.

This year, the May 30-June 1 trip will be the Prime Minister’s ninth to the state since January. Government sources confirmed that senior Kanyakumari district administration officials attended a meeting at Vivekananda Kendra on Tuesday morning for preparations.

“The PM will reach Thiruvananthapuram airport by Thursday afternoon, after wrapping up election campaign at Hoshiarpur in Punjab. He will reach the state guest house in Kanyakumari in the evening and depart for Vivekananda rock memorial by boat. He will remain there until Saturday afternoon,” said an official source. Modi will reach Kanyakumari helipad by Saturday evening and return to Thiruvananthapuram before flying back to Delhi the same night.

Kanyakumari, located at the southernmost tip of India, is a popular tourist destination – the spot of convergence of Indian Ocean, Bay of Bengal and the Arabian Sea. The rock at Kanyakumari, later converted into a memorial, made an impact on Swami Vivekananda, who meditated there for three days in Dec 1892 following extensive travels across the country.
Article Summary: PM Narendra Modi will arrive in Kanyakumari on May 30, when campaigning for the final phase of the ongoing parliamentary elections ends. During his stay, the Prime Minister will be at the Rock Memorial’s Dhyan Mandapam, the site where Swami Vivekananda meditated in 1892.

Article Title: Rishi Sunak sees 78 Tory MPs exit ahead of July poll, surpassing 1997 exodus before Tony Blair's win
Article Text:
Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (AFP photo)

There were tears, anger and frustration as many Conservative lawmakers digested their PM Rishi Sunak 's decision to call the UK elections on July 4, much earlier than they had ever expected.

Some of those fighting to retain their seats feared the six weeks left to convince skeptical voters to back them would not be enough. For others planning to stand down, it meant an abrupt end to their political careers , forced to clear out their offices months earlier than planned.Trailing Labour by over 20 percentage points in polls, Sunak, analysts said, is betting that the Tories can cut their losses by facing the voters.

But a grassroots Conservative campaign coordinator said that the morale was the lowest he had known in five decades. Tory members of parliament seem to share this sense of futility: 78 of them have opted not to contest their seats, an exodus that includes Michael Gove, who once vied for party's top post and has been at the heart of nearly every Conservative-led govt since David Cameron's in 2010. Other high profile figures who have announced they will not seek re-election include former PM Theresa May, Northern Ireland minister Chris Heaton- Harris, ex-armed forces minister James Heappey and ex-defence minister Ben Wallace.

The number of Tories exiting is more than the previous post-1945 high of 72 who quit prior to Tony Blair's 1997 landslide win for Labour, which is expected to triumph again. The departures add to a feeling that the Conservatives are on track to be kicked out of power after 14 years, although Labour require a big swing to secure a majority. Sunak's decision to go to the polls early has triggered fears that he's leading the party to one or more "Portillo" moments - when a Tory big beast loses a safe seat in an election whitewash - named for the time cabinet minister Michael Portillo lost in Enfield Southgate in 1997.
Article Summary: 78 Tory members of parliament have opted not to contest their seats. Michael Gove, who once vied for party's top post, has been at the heart of nearly every Conservative-led govt since David Cameron's in 2010. The number of Tories exiting is more than the previous post-1945 high of 72 who quit prior to Tony Blair's 1997 landslide win for Labour.
